The Buffalo Times is "far out" and lots of it. It says: "Recent events in connection with fisheries on the Atlantic coast of Canada are likely to indicate that our 'Kanuck' neighbors are more than anxious to coax a blister on the Dominion's nose. The Canadian Government has well-known leaders of the most patriotic character have been issued by the American owners of fishing vessels to observe in every way the provisions of the fisheries laws, and yet, on the slightest pretext, have been grounds that appear to the remotest manner even a technical violation, American vessels are pounced upon and subjected to embarrassing and costly delays, and to other important matters. How would it do instead of 'blotting' the Canadian nose, for the Americans to stop stealing our fish? As the Buffalo Courier says, in its letter to the local correspondent, the "If American fishing vessels would not permit in going into Canadian waters to fish, there would be much less difficulty in reaching a satisfactory settlement of fishery disputes."

During the Home Rule debate last year there were frequent matters of a coming demand for Home Rule for India. At the General Election meeting, one Indian gentleman offered himself for election with the avowed purpose of inaugurating a Home Rule movement for India, and pressing the subject at the Government, which was expected to grant that boon to Ireland. But that Government did not return to power, and we have heard little of the matter since, the tactics of the Home Rule party for India having proved a much heavier one than was anticipated by its confident adversaries. Remembering this agitation, it is somewhat astonishing to find that, little reason as there is for expecting it from Kent, Ireland, this reason is a maximum in comparison with the infinitesimal right to a similar concession possessed by India. Some degree of capacity or fitness for self-government is surely demanded before this privilege may safely be granted; but however it be in Ireland, in India there is visible next to none. It appears that the total number of graduates in Indian Universities during the twenty years preceding 1883 did amount to 5,000. There are others besides these, but it is impossible to reckon the educated natives of all classes at more than 25,000 in all. The native population is approximately 250 million. Of the 250,000 educated natives, a very carefully selected minority are fit for the Civil Service, which brings us to the result that out of 250,000,000 crying natives there is only a fraction of any size fit to take part in the business of Government, whether as civil servants, magistrates, or legislators. Evidently an Indian party in the House, to succeed the Irish aristocracy when they go to Dublin, would be premature at present.

BISHOP PINKHAM.

The Right Reverend Mr. Cyprian Pinkham, who in accordance with the wishes of His Grace, the Archbishop of Canterbury, was consecrated as Bishop of St. John's, Newfoundland, was born in St. John's, Newfoundland, in 1844. He was educated there after having had charge for a time of public school in one of the suburbs of London. He was ordained deacon in Canterbury, in 1865. During 1866 he was appointed as private tutor in the house of Sir Robert Peel. After a period of the ordinary life during 1868-1870, he was ordained as priest in the church of St. Mary Magdalene, but in this his wish was overborne by what appeared to him to be a call. After his ordination he became a member of the S.P.G., board of examiners, the secretary of the society. Mr. Ballock, officer of the society, wrote to Mr. Pinkham and thought not at first disposed to accept after earnest consultation with Canon Hackett, who had been engaged to terminate his services as organist, and a month later sailed for Canada. On his arrival in Canada Mr. Pinkham was appointed to the parish of St. John's, Newfoundland, and was elected Bishop of St. John's, Newfoundland, and was consecrated as Bishop of St. John's, Newfoundland, in 1883. In 1884 he was sent to England to study the administration of the Church, and his practical suggestions are largely due to the efficiency of the present administration of the diocese. Among the matters which may be mentioned the collegiate department in our public schools, which are superior to the high school system, but form, as it were, a link between the public school and the university examinations, a close connection between the Board of Education and the University council. In 1881 he was elected Secretary of the Council, and in 1883 Archdeacon of St. John's. He has been a member of the Provincial Council since its formation in 1874. He is also a member of the council of St. John's college and has always taken the greatest interest in its welfare. Indeed, he has been instrumental in promoting whether in organizing the diocese or planning the course of our church in general. He has been too busy to forget his services in furthering the cause of education in this country, so that the Society's work is being felt all over the district. Look at the success of the new school, which makes each one trying to get the best possible school to compete for the magnificence of the buildings and the excellence of the management. The annual membership fee of the Society is only one dollar, which enables each member to make as many entries as he chooses. Every settler interested in the advancement and welfare of this district should become a member by mailing the enclosed card. The Society financially, besides enabling the exonerated to receive a larger government grant of land. The Society are greatly in need of suitable buildings and land, and if the members will fill up it will enable them to build next year.

New York, Aug. 15.—The Herald publishes a sensational story from Ottawa to the effect that a man from Montreal, who was killed off the St. Lawrence shore of New Brunswick, says a British cruiser fired upon an American fishing schooner three days ago and sank her with all hands all on board. The stranger says that the cruiser at once put to sea, but that the American vessel was sunk by American vessel's gun by the board when she was shot from the cruiser and that the fishermen were drowned instantly. He states that there were 15 sailors drowned.

Montreal, Aug. 6.—Hon. Col. Dilworth, who accompanied the Windsor team, says the team won over £400 in prizes, and proved themselves to be equal to the best British shots.
TERRITORIAL NEWS

REGINA.

From the Leader, August 9.

Sergt. W. C. Asprey has received his promotion as Staff sergeant.

The inspection of the Indian Department buildings was being proceeded with.

Mr. Tom Wilson, of Beaver Creek, 40 miles from Saskatoon, was in town last week. He says the crops in that district have been destroyed by Rocky Mountain locusts.

Nearly all the reports received to date from various parts of the Territories refer to the harvest. Most observers say that the present harvest will prove a bountiful one.

Sergt. Farmer, for some time band master here, left on Thursday with ten men to join 1st Division at Prince Albert. Imp. Brigade. Will be with the party a portion of the way.

From the Journal, August 11.

Sergt. McPherson returned on Monday from the border. He says the Indians are friendly. He followed them into Dakota, being only half an hour behind them in crossing the river. The Indians, however, authorities refused to give him any assistance in securing the murderers. The matter, however, will not be let go, and the proper steps will be taken to obtain the offenders and efforts to secure the culprits removed.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leonard, left for Victoria, Mon., Aug. 12. Mr. Leonard has been leader and instructor of the Regina Brass Band for several years and has brought it to its present state of proficiency. The band boys assembled at the station on Tuesday night to give their departing leader a farewell dinner.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald, August 6.

On Tuesday afternoon a hail storm came down in great volume and buried the northern face of the Eagle Hills. It struck Geo. H. Harpier's fields with full force, causing considerable damage. Had there been two-thirds less crops damaged and Peter Dakton a few acres of grain the edge would have been saved. It seems that the order now of potatoes in P. H. Harpier's field was cut while the rest escaped. The hail was very heavy, coming off leaving the branches as bare as in winter, and some good hay grounds are completely ruined. Many of the hail stones were as large as a man's fist.

Some weeks ago a colony of grasshoppers attacked and ate the plains between the Bird's Nest and the Long Lake Current trail, and for the distance of about a day's travel consumed off every blade of grass. They are now stronger than their growth; they ate down everything within reach, and so starved to death. Today they lie thick upon the ground and nowhere to appear upon a smooth ground of grass, such as will make excellent feed for animals used in freighting. That same pasture is just doing harm another year.

EDMONTON.

The hail storm of Sunday (17th inst.) took ten acres of barley and damaged seven acres of oats. The wind tore the Cameron of the Sturgeon, and breaks several windows in C. Pardee's house and damages the corn crib.

An accident fell on the Sway canoe at Horn Point, Saskatoon. Lord, who was out to look for a cow, was returning this past, half a mile from the Indians' houses. Lord was killed instantly by a stone, and three miles from the H. B. post. The Indians had been watching the river, and being to board daylight the steamer came up near by the Indians, so the Indians, to prevent the steamer from entering, the appearance of a small vessel came. While still a considerable distance away, Lord was shot like the appearance of a cannon and killed instantly. The report was heard by Mr. Taylor, who was watching the Indians, who were watching the steamer. CALGARY.

From the Herald, August 12.

A number of prominent citizens called upon Mr. Wilson last night and startled Rev. Father Lacombe by presenting him with a gold watch. The prominent citizens included Mr. Ross, and among those present were: Mayor King, Major Walker, Mr. Rowe, James Ross, Mr. Alexander, Mr. Smith. Father Lacombe made a brief speech, thanking his friends for their kindness and expressing his sorrow at the death of Rev. Father Andrés. He spoke a few words. He said the reason Father Lacombe came from Calgary was because he had heard that Father Andrés along the Saskatchewan were still discontented and not disposed towards the government. He went with Andrés and restrained them during the rebellion; therefore, he thought it necessary to send messengers. Father Lacombe admitted the Indians were Indian character and who were not mixed in the relations, and who were not connected with those interests. After a cordial handshaking all round the surprise party returned to town.

GENERAL NEWS.

Paris Aug. 10. The Boulangar-Ferry affair has ceased to be a live topic in social, political, and official circles but interesting. The evidences have been laid out among the members of the league, who believe Ferry was afraid to meet Boulangar, and who think Boulangar forfeited the respect of all patriotic Frenchmen. It is contended that such men are more to be believed than the agents of terrorism. If the case can possibly be inserted and the question is commonly put forth that France were to be treated with proper respect by Germany until Boulangar's return, the war offensive a minute of her own choosing. The action of Mr. Katkov has greatly increased the animosity against Boulangar. His power, and the enemies of the commander of the thirteenth corps enlisted in the cause of the republic. Boulangar had tendered his sympathy before offering his own in order to secure another point of attack. In view of the popular popularity of the masses, the Patriarch league is a powerful organization, and Boulangar's return will be hailed. It will ever call upon his sympathizers to follow him across the German border remains to be seen.

Vienna Aug. 12. The Political Correspondence publishes a dispatch from St. Petersburg stating that in addition to the question of Russia and England have agreed, in the event of the death of the Amir, the partition of Afghanistan.

Niagara Falls, Ont., Aug. 14.—The largest crowd of people that has gathered at the Falls since the opening day of the free park was seen yesterday. The Algonquin Camp crosses the river on the ferry boat, and the crowd which is now in these waters, and King's children as an interlude, have been charged. It is said that the light machine would easily resist the turbulence of the waters when the falls, and King's boat was provided with engines before Corps reached.

ANNUAL MEETING
of the Saskatchewan Rifle Association.

The third annual meeting of the association took place on Tuesday and Friday of last week. The weather was everything that could be desired. There was a cool breeze, a cloudless blue sky, and a lovely sunshine. Friday was also a bright day. The Thursday morning was rather cool and wet, but gradually changed for the better as the day came from the north.

There was a larger number of competitors than on former occasions. Owing to some delay on the part of the Range Committee the firing did not commence until 10 o'clock, when all entries were sent in for the match.
